(Associated Press) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR GOSHEN, N.Y. (AP) — A woman accused of killing her fiance while out paddling on the Hudson River admitted tampering with his kayak and later confessed "it felt good knowing he would die," a prosecutor said Wednesday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Angelika Graswald, 35, has been indicted on a second-degree murder charge in the death of Vincent Viafore in choppy, chilly water on the evening of April 19. Police say he died 50 miles north of New York City near Bannerman Island, a scenic ruin near the east shore where the longtime U.S. resident from Latvia volunteered as a gardener. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Viafore, 46, was not wearing a life jacket and his body hasn't been found. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Assistant District Attorney Julie Mohl said at a bail hearing Wednesday that Graswald felt trapped and stood to benefit by $250,000 from life insurance policies. Mohl did not detail how Graswald tampered with her fiance's kayak but said it filled with water and capsized. Viafore held onto his boat for 5 to 10 minutes, but Graswald called 911 some 20 minutes after his kayak capsized. Witnesses say she intentionally capsized her own kayak, Mohl said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "She felt trapped and it was her only way out," Mohl said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Graswald was rescued by another boater and treated for hypothermia. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR She later told investigators that she felt relief and "it felt good knowing he would die," Mohl said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The judge set bail for Graswald, who appeared in court in shackles and an orange jumpsuit, at $3 million cash. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR After the hearing, defense attorney Richard Portale noted the language barrier between Graswald and investigators. He said he would look into whether her statements were voluntary. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I'm skeptical of the statements," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Since her arrest almost two weeks ago, those who know Graswald have been trying to square the fun-loving woman they knew with the killer described by authorities. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The bubbly, bouncy little ballerina girl had a dark side," said Mike Colvin, a disc jockey in Poughkeepsie she lived with from November 2008 to June 2010. Still, he never saw Graswald act in a way that suggested violence. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Graswald could walk into a room full of strangers and know everyone's name by the time she left, Colvin said. But he said he also had authority issues and could make unwise snap decisions when angry. She had run through two marriages and a string of jobs by her mid-30s. The impulsiveness apparently contributed to her checkered job history at restaurants and other businesses. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "They would have staff meetings, and she would just lose it, and eventually she'd have to be let go," Colvin said. "This happened more than once. Not a big fan of authority." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Graswald and Viafore appeared to be a happy couple. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Images posted online show an active, affectionate pair spending time outdoors, particularly on the water, and a message about their plans to be married at a spot on the Baltic Sea. Sean Von Clauss, a professional musician from Boston who had known Viafore since boyhood, recalls how the couple would affectionately slow dance when he performed "Shama Lama Ding Dong." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "They were always in love — singing, dancing and holding. They were always together," Von Clauss said. "He was thrilled that he found his soul mate." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Viafore had a booming laugh and loved to socialize — the kind of guy who would pick up the check, Von Clauss said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Von Clauss said he saw Graswald the Friday before her arrest at a gathering to remember Viafore at a bar. She brought a poster board covered with pictures and asked Von Clauss to play "Shama Lama Ding Dong." Usually they would play "Hotel California" together, but she asked him to play solo that night. Then she forgot the words. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We all kind of sang along, then she sort of finished it by herself," he said. "We all gave her a big round of applause anyway."
